text: Here is a quick and honest synopsis of what I wrote about the bank EPS reports early this morning on @realmoney "When I adopt the role of (harsh) critic, this morning's EPS beats by ($C) and ($JPM) were relatively poor quality - in that the better than consensus results were

chiefly related to a large drop in loan loss provisioning and reserve release. The good news is that, as discussed in yesterday's (two) columns is that there is now clear evidence of a peak in credit problems." @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @guyadami

@realmoney Oct 13, 2020 | 01:30 PM EDT DOUG KASS The Death of Banks? No Way, No How... *The jibberish about bank stocks on Fin TV is comical and uninformed I find the hysteria (The Death of Banks?) hysterical in the face of the modest declines in bank stock prices today - which

follow the recent strength over the last few weeks. I suppose we are all traders now. But I remain a bank stock investor. I am really trying to be respectful. But, how many of these playas even bothered to read the press releases, have studied the industry's balance sheet or
have bonafide spread sheets and earnings models for the individual banks? I think we know the answers to these questions. @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @threadreaderapp unroll

Now up on @realmoney Here are the Cliff Notes: My Long and Short Weightings (Part Deux) In response to continued weightings questions, here is a mid-September column which spells out my long and short weightings in a clear and precise manner: Frequently Asked Questions

* Not all investments are created equal * Risk and reward are relative concepts * And no two individuals share the same risk profile * There is an asymmetry between longs and shorts * Managing risk and attaining a "margin of safety" in long and short portfolios

@realmoney Oct 13, 2020 | 10:15 AM EDT DOUG KASS Moving to Small Sized Net Long Now *As we reached my objectives discussed three weeks ago (a gain of 350 S&P handles) Yesterday I observed that despite the outsized gain in the Nasdaq and S&P, market breadth on the NYSE was

only 3-2 positive. This was a warning sign to me and one of the conditions that led me to starting a short Index hedge. This morning market breadth more than 2-1 negative with the Nasdaq flat and the S&P down a handful. In light of the several factors discussed this morning,

I am moving back down to small in net long exposure (defined as under 20% net long): * The recent advance has likely borrowed against future fourth quarter stock price gains. * Again, as in past temporary tops, the performance has been lopsided towards FAANG plus (MSFT) .

* As a condition of the above, I don't like the underperformance of the Russell Index, which sometimes is a leading indicator of weakness in the broader averages. $IWM is down by nearly $2 or over -1%. * The spread between "fair market value" (S&P 2800-3000) and S&P cash (3535)

has widened. Though seasonality and other variables may keep the averages well above my calculus, the upside reward vs. downside risk is decidedly negative. @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @lizclaman @Sarge986 @carlquintanilla @saraeisen @terranovajoe

Taken from the Comments Section tonite on @realmoney dougie • This evening, as I reflected upon today's market action, I have to recognize that the market has fulfilled much of my optimistic and non consensus fourth quarter expectations in a relatively brief period of time

(of about three weeks). This has served to stretch out the relation of price to "fair market value" - making the market, based on my calculus, statistically overpriced and stretched. Moreover, the advance was once again concentrated in a handful of large cap tech market leaders

(several of which that I own) - which previously, in early September, marked a temporary market top. Market breadth on the NYSE was only about 3-2 positive, disappointing relative to the S&P cash advance of sixty handles and the Nasdaq rise of 300 handles. Today I sold out the

balance of my SPY long rental - but I am still exposed (medium sized) on a net long basis. As a consequence I have shorted positions in S&P and Nasdaq futures (in the after hours) to reduce my net exposure. It is time to take the foot of the accelerator. @jimcramer @tomkeene
